title: Is there a reason that the covers of TIME magazine feature some people in front of the logo, while others are not? - Quora
tags: Time Magazine's Person of the Year

response.answer_text: I can’t speak for TIME, but having designed numerous covers for three different magazines, I can offer an opinion that I’m willing to wager is correct. It comes down to the actual image chosen and the cover design. (One might have also assumed it depends on who the cover personality is and how well-known they were, but a look through the TIME archives tells me that assumption is incorrect). Rather than cherry-pick covers, a good place to start is the TIME Vault, where you can see pretty much every cover the magazine has ever published. Here, for example, are the thumbnails for covers for 2014, 2015 and until May 2016 (click to zoom in):  The key thing to look for is how well defined the edge of the element being overlaid on the TIME masthead is. (The element is usually, but not always, the head). If it’s a crisp edge – such as the complete head being used – chances are it will be overlaid, like in these examples:  If, however, the face is being “bled” off the page (that’s design-speak for part of the face being cropped), then it will almost always go behind the masthead, like with these covers:  However – and this is where design sensibilities come into play – there will be exceptions to these rules. With the first set of cover images, the designer has a choice of whether or not to have the logo partially covered. And it’s only a well-recognized publication like TIME that can get away with this treatment…for a smaller, less-well known magazine to do this would simply be foolish. Now that you recognize what the norm is, here are a few TIME covers that break the rules:  With the first, the head does in fact bleed off the page, but the clean edge and position of the face in the image mandates it being overlaid on the masthead. In the second, the smoke doesn’t offer the clean edge, but having it swirl around the logo is a better effect than were it to go behind. And with the third, Pope Francis could have been used either in front or behind (a point I made earlier). In this case, the designer chose to have the logo in front, but a previous cover where he was named Person of the Year in 2013, had him in front.

Most people on the cover of the magazine ( I don't think Kanye West falls under the same league as Mandela and Putin! :p) are some of the most influential people of their times. They are the ones who mould the future.  So my logic is simple..if you have the ability to shape the future(time) you must be the one who stays ahead of his/her time! .. Both literally and figuratively.
